name: Evidentiary Features
description: The top-level category for all of evidence that can be extracted from digital media to perform forensic tasks.

children.name: Model Ingested
children.description: Features primarily designed to be processed by computational models and algorithms, which may not be directly perceptible or interpretable by a human analyst.
examples: Raw pixel values fed into a neural network.
Statistical moments of a color channel histogram.
Wavelet transform coefficients used for classification.
associated_terms: 3d-cnn model to produce the spatial-temporal features
6 feature vectors in parallel from both the real image and its replica
a self-attention module is used to extract global feature information
aligned image feature, using the image encoder of clip
an encoder based on a cnn to extract features

neural representation reconstruction error can highlight the manipulation trace

semantic information embedded in the image

text encoder from clip to obtain aligned text features
textual and visual features of each text-image pair
use a decoder, a long short-term memory (lstm) network, to describe them by different words
vggish model to extract the audio features

children.name: Metadata & File Structure
children.description: Analysis of the file's container and metadata, which can reveal the media's origin, processing history, and structural integrity.
examples: Analyzing EXIF data to find discrepancies between the creation date and the camera model's release date.
Identifying invalid or non-standard file headers that indicate file corruption or manual editing.

children.name: Hand-Crafted Features
children.description: Specific, manually engineered features extracted from media signals, designed to capture known artifacts of creation or manipulation.
examples: Using Photo-Response Non-Uniformity (PRNU) to match an image to a specific camera sensor.
Applying Steganalysis Rich Models (SRM) filters to detect hidden noise.
Calculating Mel-frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCCs) from an audio file to analyze speech characteristics.

children.name: Spatial Domain Features
children.description: Features extracted directly from the pixel values and their spatial relationships within a single frame or image.
examples: Detecting inconsistencies in noise patterns across different regions of an image.
Analyzing the color filter array (CFA) interpolation patterns for signs of digital tampering.
associated_terms: absolute difference of the rgb pixel values
affinity matrix based on the extracted feature vectors at every pixel
bayarconv to obtain the noise feature
common features in the same image but from different qualities
contextual information of images from the web
cosine similarity between recovered image and manipulated image and all learned templates in the set
difference between explicit and implicit identity of face
differences between forged face with its surrounding regions
differences between real and fake samples
discriminative fine-grained texture containing oneâ€™s identity information
edges between the tampered regions and untampered regions
fake texture produced by upsampling methods
feature differences of surfaces and textures in splicing forgery images
forgery clues captured by decoder features
geometrical representations, known as surface frames
global semantic information of the image
heuristics from human annotations and the features learned from neural networks
hierarchical feature representation of different operations
high frequency component of the shallow features
high-frequency representation of features across spatial and channel dimensions
high-order relation of spatial and frequency features
high-related features from the other image
image generation artifacts that can exist in both rgb and frequency domain
inconsistencies in the features around the tampered boundary
inherent inconsistency: disparity between real and inherent manipulated regions
intrinsic forgery clues on both spatial and frequency domains
latent representations from the frequency transformation of image patches (blocks)
local artifacts from the spatio-frequency domain
local features by considering only perceptually significant spatial regions
local features that are learned by a cnn
local forgery traces within image and frequency domains
local relative correlation between pixels in local patches
local semantic information of the image

low-level scene attributes related to the camera acquisition process

mean of speech and facial valence and arousal
metric space that co-locates similar illumination and in-camera processing artifacts
microscopic features relevant to forgery images
mutual information between diï¬€erent image blocks
noise features by high pass filters
noise image xt by ddim inversion
noise residuals and low-level rgb features
pattern features for the cross-modal inconsistency
pixel values in the surrounding background in the pixel domain
relation-aware features in spatial and frequency domains
rgb feature and the edge feature
root mean squared error (rmse) between the input and output images
ssim similarity between the reversed images and the original images
statistical information of the original image
statistical regularities typical of natural and undistorted images
the distribution of the pixels of the image
the structure of the transpose convolution layers
three different types of features together. classic 2d convolutional layer, steganalysis rich model (srm) filter [1] and constrained convolutional layer
traces left by the process of demosaicing
we apply a wavelet-based filter to extract noise patterns for each face
â€œdevice fingerprintâ€ from the cmos image sensor based puf
fine-grained texture containing oneâ€™s identity information
horizontal texture features and vertical texture features

children.name: Texture Based
children.description: Features that characterize the surface appearance or structural patterns in an image or a single frame.

children.name: Gradient
children.description: Measures the rate of change in intensity of pixels in an image.
examples: Analyzing gradient magnitudes to detect smoothing or blurring artifacts in manipulated regions.
associated_terms: gradients of a trained cnn model

children.name: Co-occurrence Matrix
children.description: A method that captures how often pairs of pixel intensity values occur in spatial relation to each other
examples: Using gray-level co-occurrence patterns to identify tampered areas with inconsistent structural repetition.

children.name: Local Binary Patterns LBP
children.description: A texture descriptor that encodes the local spatial structure of an image by comparing each pixel to its surrounding neighbors.
examples: Using LBP to reveal unnatural texture transitions in a region suspected of manipulation.

children.name: Entropy
children.description: A measure of the randomness or complexity of pixel values in a region.
examples: Calculating local entropy to identify regions with unexpectedly low complexity due to over-smoothing.

children.name: Edge Map
children.description: An image highlighting the boundaries and edges of objects.
examples: Locating unnaturally sharp or blurry edges around a spliced object.
associated_terms: canny edge detector to extract edge map
rgb feature and the edge feature

children.name: Keypoint
children.description: Distinctive points in an image (e.g., corners, blobs) used for matching and tracking.
examples: Detecting duplicated regions by matching SIFT keypoints across different parts of an image.

children.name: Color Based
children.description: Features derived from color distributions or relationships within an image or a single frame.

children.name: Color Histogram
children.description: A representation of the distribution of colors in an image or a single frame.
examples: Comparing color histograms between regions to detect inserted objects with mismatched color profiles.

children.name: Color Filter Array Bayer
children.description: A pattern used in digital cameras to capture color information.
examples: Detecting forgeries by finding inconsistencies in the expected CFA pattern across the image.
associated_terms: traces left by the process of demosaicing

children.name: Color Differences
children.description: Features computed by measuring the difference in color values between adjacent pixels or regions.
examples: Calculating pixel-wise color differences to highlight abrupt transitions.

children.name: Noise Based
children.description: Features that analyze the statistical or signal-level noise characteristics across an image or a single frame.
associated_terms: noise features by high pass filters
noise image xt by ddim inversion
noise residuals and low-level rgb features

children.name: PRNU Noise
children.description: Photo-Response Non-Uniformity (PRNU) is a sensor-level noise pattern unique to each camera.
examples: Verifying if two images were taken by the same camera by comparing their PRNU patterns.
Detecting spliced regions by identifying inconsistencies or absence of PRNU noise in localized areas.

children.name: SRM Features
children.description: Spatial Rich Models (SRM) are high-dimensional, hand-crafted feature sets designed to capture statistical irregularities in pixel-level residuals.
examples: Detecting hidden artifacts introduced by editing tools through image SRM noise residuals.
associated_terms: srm filters to extract noise map

children.name: Frequency Domain Features
children.description: Features extracted by transforming the image from the spatial domain to the frequency domain, typically using transforms like DCT or FFT, to capture periodic patterns, compression artifacts, or editing traces not easily visible in pixel space.
examples: Detecting grid-like artifacts from the Discrete Cosine Transform (DCT).
Detecting manipulation traces by examining high-frequency suppression caused by local smoothing
associated_terms: amplitude and phase spectrum of images
amplitude spectrum and phase spectrum of feature maps
coarse features from the imageâ€™s frequency domain
coarse-grained dct and fine-grained dct to capture the local frequency cues
energy variations in spectrum and lip movements
high frequency component of the shallow features
high-order relation of spatial and frequency features
latent representations from the frequency transformation of image patches (blocks)
local artifacts from the spatio-frequency domain
multi-band frequencies using a laplacian of gaussian (log)
spectral features in the input audio
the real valued part of the discrete fourier transform (dft)
transform the rgb images to 2d spectrum by applying the fast fourier transform (fft) on each channel

children.name: Discrete Cosine Transform DCT
children.description: A frequency transform that decomposes an image into a sum of cosine functions at various frequencies. Commonly used in JPEG compression.
examples: Analyzing DCT coefficient histograms to detect double compression.

children.name: Fast Fourier Transform FFT
children.description: An efficient algorithm to compute the Discrete Fourier Transform.
examples: Finding periodic noise patterns in an image that suggest digital editing.

children.name: Discrete Wavelet Transform DWT
children.description: A transform that decomposes an image into multiple sub-bands at different scales and orientations, capturing both spatial and frequency information.
examples: Detecting inconsistencies in wavelet coefficients across scales that may indicate tampered regions.
associated_terms: different frequency bands of discrete wavelet transform (dwt)
discrete wavelet transformations (dwt) to yield frequency-decoupled image features

children.name: Mel-frequency Cepstral Coefficients (MFCC)
children.description: A set of features that represent the short-term power spectrum of audio signals on a mel scale.
examples: Identifying artifacts in synthesized audio that manifest as unnatural MFCC sequences.
Using MFCC features alongside facial features to detect mismatches between speech and lip movements in deepfake videos.
associated_terms: mel frequency cepstral coefficients (mfcc) speech features

children.name: Temporal Domain Features
children.description: Features that analyze how media content changes over time, primarily used for video and audio.
examples: Tracking the flow of pixels between video frames to identify manipulated movement.
associated_terms: inconsistency from global spatial and temporal perspectives using the self-attention mechanism
inter-frame inconsistencies of multiple frames from a global perspective
long and short range inter-frame motions
spatial and temporal information extracted from a video sequence
spatiotemporal characteristics of the input video
standard deviations of all the four time-series
temporal difference of the identity vectors
temporal synchronization between video frames and sound
temporal variations within style latent vectors
two adjacent frames' signal-to-noise ratio (psnr), mean squared error (mse), structural similarity index measure (ssim), pearson correlation coefficient (pcc), frechet inception distance

children.name: Optical Flow Field
children.description: The pattern of apparent motion of objects between two consecutive frames.
examples: Analyzing optical flow fields to detect unnatural or inconsistent motion patterns caused by frame interpolation or object insertion.
associated_terms: optical flow between two successive frames

children.name: Compression Artifacts
children.description: Visual distortions introduced by lossy image or video compression algorithms.
examples: Identifying blocking artifacts around a spliced object that don't align with the rest of the image's JPEG grid.
Detecting different levels of compression in different parts of an image, suggesting a composite.
associated_terms: periodic artefacts, such as cfa, resampling and jpeg artefacts

children.name: Deep Features
children.description: High-level, abstract features learned automatically by deep neural networks from vast amounts of data.
examples: Using the output of a pre-trained face recognition network (e.g., FaceNet) to see if a face is synthetic.
Extracting features from a CNN like ResNet-50 to classify an image as real or AI-generated.

children.name: Textual Embedding
children.description: Numerical representations of text.
examples: Using BERT embeddings to represent the caption of a social media post and compare it with visual content for semantic consistency.
associated_terms: all nouns as a general textual context
cosine similarity matrix of image regions to word pairs
features from frame sequence, audio sequence, and transcript
high-level embeddings of images and prompts
precise news high-order knowledge semantic information
representations respectively from the views of the text, the image pattern and the image semantics
self-written and verified introduction of the publisher and feed it into the pre-trained bert
semantic features from image and text respectively
speaker referring to an object that is not present in the scene, or vice-versa
textual representation enhanced by visual entities
video transcript and concatenate it with the title

children.name: Visual Embedding
children.description: Numerical representations of visual content.
examples: Using embeddings from a pretrained ResNet or Vision Transformer (ViT) to determine if a face is a deepfake.
associated_terms: aligned image feature, using the image encoder of clip
cosine similarity between pairs of image features
embeddings extracted by the backbone network

features of real images, real reconstructed images, generated images using stable diffusion v1.4, and the generated-then-reconstructed images, from the last feature layer before the classification layers in a pre-trained detector convnext-base
high-level embeddings of images and prompts

output of the final layer of the image encoder and the output of the text encoder
pre-trained cnn backbone to extract image features
pre-trained vgg19 model to extract the image feature

representations respectively from the views of the text, the image pattern and the image semantics

semantic correlation of images and texts
semantic features from image and text respectively
semantic information embedded in the image
structural information of labeled pixel embeddings
tampered trace features extracted from different block by encoder
textual and visual features of each text-image pair

children.name: Audio Embedding
children.description: Numerical representations of audio content.
examples: Leveraging Whisper embeddings to verify alignment between speech and visual cues in talking-head videos.
associated_terms: mel frequency cepstral coefficients (mfcc) speech features
pre-trained vggish model to extract audio feature
spectral features in the input audio
vggish model to extract the audio features

children.name: Human Understandable
children.description: Evidentiary cues that can be perceived and logically interpreted by a human analyst without necessarily requiring complex computational tools.
examples: A person in a video not blinking for an extended period.
Shadows that are cast in a direction inconsistent with the visible light sources.
A reflection in a mirror that does not match the scene.
associated_terms: ai-synthesis artifacts annotated by multiple users
basic features from the text, the image and the generated image captions

children.name: Biometric Signals
children.description: Cues related to the unique biological and behavioral traits of an individual.
examples: Analyzing the rhythm of a person's heartbeat as captured by subtle color changes in their skin (photoplethysmography).
Observing unnatural or robotic facial expressions that don't match the emotional context.
associated_terms: a static biometric based on facial identity
a temporal, behavioral biometric based on facial expressions and head movements
identity information of the inner face as well as the outer face

children.name: Facial Movement
children.description: Encompasses all cues related to the motion of the face, including expressions, eye movement, and lip synchronization.
examples: Observing robotic or unnatural sequences of facial movements, such as a smile appearing instantly rather than organically.
Detecting a mismatch between an emotional expression (e.g., a frown) and the context of the speech.
associated_terms: adjusted facial rgb pixel values is then converted to hsv
correlation between lip movements and head postures
detailed spatial information about facial muscle tissue, such as facial skin, hair distribution, color and wrinkles
dynamic information of the lip movements describing the userâ€™s talking habit
facial attribute features including gender, age, and race
fine-grained differences of shape, texture and motion in landmarks
local and global consistencies among all facial parts
semantically high-level irregularities in mouth motion
social context of the perceived face
spherical harmonic reflectance on the mean texture
the cameraâ€™s roll and pitch from a single rgb image
the shape and the position of facial organs
underlying variance in the landmark movement

children.name: Facial Expression
children.description: The movement and positioning of facial muscles to convey emotion.
examples: Noticing a 'puppet-like' smile that doesn't engage the correct muscles around the eyes (a non-Duchenne smile).
An expression of surprise that lacks the corresponding eyebrow raise.

children.name: Blinking
children.description: The act of closing and opening the eyelids.
examples: Observing a complete lack of blinking or an unnaturally consistent blinking rate in a deepfake subject.

children.name: Lip Motion
children.description: The movement of the lips during speech.
examples: Poor lip-sync where the audio does not match the mouth movements.
Unnatural shapes of the mouth (visemes) for certain sounds.
associated_terms: inconsistencies in mouth and teeth shapes across different frames

children.name: Gaze
children.description: The direction and focus of the eyes.
examples: Detecting unnatural eye darting or a fixed stare that is inconsistent with human behavior.
Eyes that do not properly track an object in the scene.

children.name: Physiological Traces
children.description: Cues related to involuntary biological processes that can be captured from media. These are often subtle and require specific analysis, but are very difficult to fake convincingly.

children.name: Heartbeat Rhythm
children.description: Subtle physiological signals, such as variations in skin color due to blood flow, that can be extracted from facial regions in video to estimate pulse or heart rate.
examples: Using remote photoplethysmography (rPPG) to detect an absent or unnatural heart rate in a deepfake video.

children.name: Pupil Shape
children.description: The geometry and consistency of a personâ€™s pupils across video frames.
examples: Analyzing pupil shape and symmetry to detect artifacts in AI-generated faces.

children.name: Body Motion
children.description: Cues related to the movement of the entire body or significant parts of it, such as the head and limbs.

children.name: Head Pose
children.description: The orientation and movement of the head.
examples: Identifying jerky or unnatural head movements that don't align with the body's posture.

children.name: Gait
children.description: A person's manner of walking.
examples: Analyzing a synthesized full-body video to find an unnatural or physically impossible gait.

children.name: Geometric Structural Inconsistency
children.description: Cues related to errors in the shape, structure, and spatial arrangement of objects.
examples: A person's glasses having an inconsistent shape from one frame to the next.
Architectural lines that should be parallel but appear to converge incorrectly.
associated_terms: geometrical representations, known as surface frames
inconsistencies in mouth and teeth shapes across different frames
local and global consistencies among all facial parts

children.name: Blending Boundary
children.description: The transition region between a manipulated area and its surrounding content in an image or video, where visual inconsistencies in texture, color, or edge smoothness may indicate manipulation.
examples: Identifying a visible, blurry, or discolored line around a face that has been swapped onto another person's head.

children.name: Face Asymmetries
children.description: Inconsistencies or unnatural deviations in the geometric or structural symmetry of a face
examples: Noticing that one earring is clear while the other is a distorted blob, a common GAN artifact.

children.name: Warping
children.description: Distortions in the background or surrounding areas caused by manipulation.
examples: Seeing straight lines in the background (like a door frame) become curved or wavy around a manipulated object.

children.name: Violation Of Physics
children.description: Cues where the media depicts events or properties that contradict the laws of physics.
examples: An object that has no shadow on a sunny day.
A ball bouncing in a way that defies gravity.

children.name: Lighting
children.description: The way light interacts with objects and surfaces in the scene.
examples: A person's face being lit from the left while all other objects in the scene are lit from the right.

children.name: Shadow
children.description: The dark areas created by an object blocking light.
examples: An object casting multiple shadows from a single light source.

children.name: Corneal Reflection
children.description: The reflection of the surrounding environment visible in the cornea of the eye.
examples: Analyzing a high-resolution photo and finding that the reflection in the subject's eyes does not match the scene they are supposedly in.

children.name: Perspective
children.description: The representation of three-dimensional objects on a two-dimensional surface.
examples: Identifying an object that was inserted into a photo because its vanishing points do not align with the rest of the scene.

children.name: Temporal Inconsistency
children.description: Artifacts that occur or change over time in a video or audio stream.
examples: A logo on a t-shirt that flickers or disappears in some frames.
An audio recording where the background noise suddenly changes or cuts out.
associated_terms: inconsistency from global spatial and temporal perspectives using the self-attention mechanism
inter-frame inconsistencies of multiple frames from a global perspective
long and short range inter-frame motions
spatial and temporal information extracted from a video sequence
temporal difference of the identity vectors
temporal synchronization between video frames and sound
temporal variations within style latent vectors
two adjacent frames' signal-to-noise ratio (psnr), mean squared error (mse), structural similarity index measure (ssim), pearson correlation coefficient (pcc), frechet inception distance

children.name: Flickering Jitter
children.description: Rapid and inconsistent changes in brightness, color, or position.
examples: Observing a deepfaked face that subtly flickers or has unstable textures between frames.

children.name: Semantic Coherence
children.description: Refers to the logical and contextual consistency of objects and events within a scene over time.
examples: A person's glasses disappearing and reappearing between frames.
A background object changing its position or state illogically from one scene cut to another.
A speaker referring to an object that is not present in the scene, or vice-versa.

children.name: Cross Modal Inconsistency
children.description: Contradictions between different modalities of media, such as audio, video, and text.
examples: A video showing a dog barking, but the audio track contains the sound of a cat meowing.
A news banner (text) describing a scene in Paris, while the video clearly shows landmarks from Rome.
associated_terms: natural correspondence between the visual and auditory modalities
pattern features for the cross-modal inconsistency
semantic relevance between text and the visual frames
sentiment resonance between audio and text
synchronization features: audio-visual features that are designed to convey the temporal alignment between vision and sound
synergy between audio and visual speech elements
temporal synchronization between video frames and sound
textual and visual features of each text-image pair

children.name: Audio-Visual
children.description: Inconsistencies between what is seen and what is heard.
examples: Poor lip synchronization in a deepfake video.
Seeing a car crash on screen but hearing the sound a split-second too late.
associated_terms: audio-visual inconsistency at temporal and spatial levels
correlation between lip movements and head postures
mean of speech and facial valence and arousal

children.name: Visual-Textual
children.description: Inconsistencies between visual information and accompanying text.
examples: A caption describing a 'sunny beach' for an image that clearly depicts a snowy mountain.
associated_terms: all nouns as a general textual context
correlation degree between caption and image
cosine similarity matrix of image regions to word pairs
precise news high-order knowledge semantic information
semantic correlation of images and texts
semantic relevance between text and the visual frames
textual representation enhanced by visual entities
video transcript and concatenate it with the title
